awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively-Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometer (ICP-MS) System at Missouri State University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs.  Professor Cyren Rico from Missouri State University and colleagues Richard Biagioni, Robert Pavlowsky, Gary Michelfelder and Melissa Remley have acquired an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS). In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex matrices. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized and the ion masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. The ionization using an inductively coupled plasma allows detection of metal ions and several non-metals present in very small concentrations. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and regional area. It is used by many students, some underrepresented in science. Fields of study include analytical, environmental, geochemical, and agricultural sciences. The ICP-MS also contributes toward outreach to other local universities such as Evangel University and Ozark Technical Community College. It is used for educational program targeting women and first generation college students since no academic institution in southwest Missouri has ICP-MS capability.


The award of the ICP-MS is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas. It especially impacts studies of fate, transport, toxicity, and food chain transfer of engineered nanomaterials as well as plant/soil interaction with environmental stressors. The instrument is also used to analyze nutrient and geochemical cycling. The mass spectrometer is employed for trace elements analysis in biological, food, dietary supplements, and environmental samples. Some examples are sediments, soil, volcanic rocks, drinking water, wastewater, effluents, and plants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ICP-MS awarded to Missouri State University (MSU) was installed in October 2018. The MRI grant facilitated the awarding of other internal and external grants that built up the capability of Chemistry Department to perform elemental analysis using ICP-MS. The Provost Office, other Departments/Units (Biology, Geology, Ozarks Environmental and Water Research Institute), and alumni donors provided financial support for the acquisition of other instruments and accessories (e.g., Laser Ablation instrument, CEM microwave digestion machine, ball mill grinder, standards, etc). Research professors and students from several units at MSU including chemistry, biology, geology, material science, and agriculture perform elemental analysis in the Department and therefore take advantage of using these instruments and pieces of equipment. Our elemental analysis capability is being used in several teaching labs particularly the Advanced Instrumental Analysis Lab, Environmental Chemistry Lab, Geochemical Methods, Petrology, and Special Topics in Chemistry. MSU has now the capability to prepare (i.e., grinding and digestion) and analyze environmental samples in ICP-MS (either solution or ablation), which provides competitive training for students, improves research capability and outputs at MSU, and increases the chance of researchers to apply for external grants. However, significant challenges from COVID-19 lockdowns and repairs/maintenance of the instrument hampered research/teaching activities.

PI Cyren Rico benefited from the elemental analysis capability at MSU by publishing two research papers with three more manuscripts currently being prepared, presenting at least 10 papers in local and national conferences, submitting two proposals to the National Science Foundations and Research Corporation for Science Advancement using preliminary data collected from our elemental analyses in plants, and training 12 undergraduate students and four graduate students in using the ICP-MS for research activities. PI Rico?s lab assisted research groups from Biology Department (Dr. Babur Mirza, Dr. La Toya Kissoon-Charles (senior personnel in this grant), and Dr. Laszlo Kovacs) for elemental analysis needs in diverse research projects. Dr. Rico?s research group also established collaborations with researchers from US EPA in Corvallis, Oregon, the University of Florida in Fort Pierce, Florida, and Pittsburg State University in Kansas to support their studies on elemental uptake of nanoparticles in plants and heavy metals implications to community health. Currently, Dr. Rico is also exploring potential collaborations with researchers from Mindoro State University to build their capabilities in their efforts for a more sustainable management of Naujan National Lake Park in Mindoro, Philippines.

Interdisciplinary work involving the ICP-MS between the Co-PI Richard Biagioni in the Chemistry Department and the Co-PI Melissa Bledsoe in Environmental Plant Science and Natural Resources Department involves a three-year study of garlic. This project involved extensive training on the instrument of one undergraduate student and one M.S. in Plant Science thesis student in the College of Agriculture. Students developed standards and methods for analysis of hundreds of samples of garlic bulbs and leaves.

Acquisition of the peripheral accessories, specifically the laser ablation system, has allowed Co-PI Gary Michelfelder to add in situ elemental analysis of geologic materials to the analytical capabilities of the ICP-MS. Currently, four external grants to NASA and NSF have been funded since 2018 using preliminary data collected on the instrument. Two manuscripts are in publication using this data and four more manuscripts are in review or in preparation to be submitted by the end of the calendar year. Co-PI Michelfelder has nine current M.S. students using data collected on the instrument and funded off external grants that are a direct result of the MRI, along with funding six undergraduate research projects since 2018. Development of new analytical techniques are under development which will build new collaborations with MSU faculty from Physics and Material Sciences (Drs. Besara and Cornelison), and Chemistry (Drs. Rico (Project PI), DeVore, Wang, and Gerasimchuk) to develop in situ analysis methods in a variety of projects, but specifically focused on chemical variation within crystalline materials. Michelfelder?s group has also expanded outside of the MSU to develop collaboration with international partners in Chile, Germany, Italy, and Argentina and within the United States at the University of Iowa and the University of Arkansas.
